title: Obama: U.S. strike won't end Iran's nuclear program - CNNPolitics.com
text:
What's next: Iran nuclear talks resume in Vienna 05:07 Washington (CNN) Conducting a military strike on Iran would stall the country's nuclear program but ultimately wouldn't stop Tehran from obtaining a nuclear weapon, President Barack Obama said in an interview with an Israeli television station. Obama and his administration have one month to finalize a deal with Tehran to curb its nuclear activity. Critics of the agreement, including Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, claim it will empower Iran by loosening longstanding sanctions without sufficient concessions in return. READ: Cruz, Christie go after Obama on Israel But the President told Israel's Channel 2 Friday that the deal he hopes to complete by July 1 is the only way to keep Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon. "The best way to prevent Iran from having a nuclear weapon is a verifiable, tough, agreement," he said in a excerpt of the interviewed released Monday. "A military solution will not fix it, even if the United States participates. It would temporarily slow down an Iranian nuclear program but it would not eliminate it." Hide Caption 38 of 38 The proposed deal with Iran has strained U.S.-Israel ties, with Obama repeatedly defending his commitment to Israel's security. He spoke last month at a synagogue in Washington and told the audience that the Iran deal would ensure Iran doesn't acquire nuclear weapons. In the Channel 2 interview, Obama told Israelis: "I understand your concerns and I understand your fears."
